review_blob: Dark mahogany pour with a lot of red highlights. Beige head thats a little on the short side. Lots of red and purple fruit on the nose with hint of confectioners sugar. Feels about the same on the palate but theres a big burst of licorice for me that I cant decide if Im really a fan of. It was quite shocking on the first sip.

Mahogany pour with a light beige head that lasts for days. Lots of cooked fruit and spice on the nose Theres also a bready character in there. A little warm on the palate but full of spice and bread notes with some cooked fruit. Solid but not especially exciting.

Near black pour with a tan head of tight bubbles. Grainy nose with light molasses notes. Theres also a foresty sort of aroma that I cant quite define. Much less grain on the palate. Light molasses and that foresty note. A touch of licorice. Medium body. Im not sure what to make of this.

Dark brown pour with lots of tan head that sticks around for quite some time. Chocolaty roasted malt on the nose with some leafy hop character. A little thin on the palate with a roasted coffee flavour dominating. Theres a slight nutty quality as well. Finishes quite dry with a light lingering bitterness.

Light amber pour with a nearly white single finger head. Leaves a thin cap and a ring. Interesting nose on this stuff; theres smoke and spice and fruit and bread and something candied. Just as impressive on the palate. All those same notes come together nicely. The only downside I see is a weird astringent hiccup leading into the spicy finish.

Dark brown pour with red highlights. Tan head that leaves a thin cap of lace. Aromas of dark chocolate, licorice, sour berries and toffee. Much the same in the flavour profile. The cranberry doesnt come through until late and follows into the finish. Good, interesting stuff but seems to fall outside the stout category in my mind.
beer_name: Muskoka Winter Beard Double Chocolate Cranberry Stout

review_blob: Nearly black pour with a tan head that sticks around nicely. Lots of bright hop character on the nose with something thats like a cross between candy and medicine. Theres a light roasted malt note underneath. The hop character dominates on the palate as well but the dark maltiness comes out a little better. The finish isnt quite as long and sharp as I might like but overall this is good drinkable beer.

Cloudy yellowy pour with a frothy white head that sticks around and leaves a lot of webbing. Fresh pineapple, pine and a candy note on the nose. A little light of flavour, some pineapple and pine but not much else really. Finishes with a persistent bitterness.

Nearly black pour with a finger of tan head. Roasted coffee and cinnamon on the nose. More cinnamon on the palate with some chocolate and coffee notes. Theres also a bit of earthiness. Medium bodied with a lengthy bitter and spicy finish.

Nearly black pour with a finger of mocha head that leaves a good layer of lace. Chocolate dominates the nose as one might expect. I get layers and layers of different chocolate notes, milk chocolate, hot chocolate, fresh fudge. Theres also a nice vanillan note wrapped around the chocolate. Theres a nice little licorice note added on the palate as well as a faint bitterness that offsets the light sweetness. Finishes with a drawn out slightly warming bittersweet chocolaty note.

Clear, copper pour with a slightly yellow head that leaves a little lace. Lots of resinous hops on the nose with slightly burnt grain and stewed fruit. Fairly sweet on the palate with lots of roasted grain notes, deep hop flavours and rich fruit. Finishes a little on the warm side, but a pleasant sipper.
beer_name: Les Trois Mousquetaires G.C. Barleywine Amricain

review_blob: Cloudy light amber pour with several miles of head. Lots of funk and wood notes on the nose with some light fruit notes. Moderately sour with a little more fruit character in the mouth. Finishes with a mild sourness that lingers nicely.

Light amber pour with forgettable amounts of head that leave a thin ring of lace. This is a weird one on the nose. Im getting a fairly strong note of sweet fuel on top of what might be spruce. Theres also a nice hint of freshly removed band-aid. The spruce onslaught on the palate is immediate and intense. After the first shocking taste there comes a wave of sweetness that carries that fuelly note from the nose. Theres something in here that reminds me of cheap ginger ale as well. Finishes with a spruce filled bitter note. Theres something a little oily about the texture too. This is a big miss for me.

Dark brown pour with amber highlights and a tan head that leaves a solid ring of lace. The nose features roasted notes and some caramel maltiness with fruit forward hop notes that aslo feature some spice and spruce notes. Pretty juicy fruit notes on the palate with a nice malt note that kicks in on the mid-palate. Finishes with an earthy, citric note. 

Not as hop forward as the deScription might lead one to expect and a little thin in body but overall quite pleasant.

Hazy amber pour with a fairy fluffy white head that leaves a decent amount of lace. Lots of fruit and floral notes on the nose with a hint of funkiness. Quite similar on the palate with a dry, slightly tart finish.
Smells like Sprite or 7Up...I cant remember which is which. Taste is less sweet than expected. Inoffensive but not much going on. Better than expected.

Rusted copper pour with an eggshell head that doesnt leave much lace. Theres a lot of raisin and prune on the nose here with some dank spruce notes. The same can be said of the palate. Id have guessed this was old as shit but the BB date is June 2015. This stuff drinks like a light barleywine. Decent enough but godawful if were talking style.

765ml? bottle. Light golden pour with a white head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving a bit of lace. Fairly funky nose with some apple notes and a certain white wine quality. On the palate theres an interesting slice note with a more notable wine character. The funk is a little less pronounced and the finish lasts quite a while.

Hazy amber pour with an almost white head thats a little short but leaves nice lacing. Big nose full of candied citrus fruit, pineapple and spruce with enough maltiness behind it to balance out. Pretty sweet candied fruit on the front that leads into a healthy bitterness and long finish. Great stuff.

Clear copper pour with lots of pillowy head that leaves a little lace. Lots of bready notes with some roasted character, light toffee. Theres something floral about this as well. Mostly the same on the palate. Finishes slightly sweet with a good malt flavour. Impressive for the style.

Crystal clear golden pour with minimal head that disappears in seconds. Fairly grainy nose with a touch of earthiness and fruit. Pretty bland on the palate as well. I wouldnt say theres anything particularly Belgian about this.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Petit Sault Bob LeBoeuf

review_blob: Lightly cloudy light golden pour with a fairly non-existent head. Coriander and light citric notes on the nose. Theres something almost sulphury about it. The fruit comes out a lot better on the palate with some mild spiciness. Wheat flavours come out as well. Finishes dry with a light spice note. Decent enough.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Petit Sault Tante Blanche

review_blob: Nearly black pour with an average tan head that has good staying power. Leaves a little lace. Light coffee and dark fruit on the nose with a nice earthy touch. A lot of coffee in the mouth which overpowers a lot of the subtler notes from the nose. Good, but not great.

Dark copper pour with fairly minimal tan head that leaves a thin ring of lace. Lots of pumpkin pie spiciness on the nose with a nice maltiness underneath. More spice on the palate. Its a little more cinnamon driven than Id like. I keep thinking of those tooth chipping red heart candies. The maltiness from the nose is more subdued as well. Not a bad effort.

Pours a clean dark copper with beige head that sticks around nicely. Those nose is a powerhouse of spice. Theres a little pumpkin in there as well but this really smells more like gingerbread than pumpkin pie to me. The flavour says all the same things. The ginger is a little less dominant on the palate and the pumpkin comes through a bit more but this stuff is quite hot in the mouth. Finishes with a real spicy note and lingering heat.
beer_name: Flying Monkeys Paranormal Imperial Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: Rusted orange pour with an average off-white head that leaves a decent amount of lace. Dense citrus dominates the nose with some lighter pine notes and caramel underneath. Mostly the same on the palate. Finishes with a lot of that dense citrus note and high bitterness. A quality brew but it doesnt really stand out in the sea of IIPAs for me.

Lightly cloudy amber leaning towards orange pour with a quick off-white head that leaves the thinnest of rings of lace. I get a lot of bananas and funk on the nose here. Lactic notes and some wood. Theres a bit of apple in there too. Pleasantly tart on the palate but missing some of the complexity of the nose. Its good but theres something missing.

Clear amber pour with an average head that leaves a hint of lace. Extremely light on the nose, to the point where I had to go smell other things to make sure I hadnt lost my sense of smell. What aroma there is seems to be just grain with a hint of roastiness. Theres a little more going on in the mouth but not much. Theres a light fruitiness and some of that lightly toasted grain. Finishes with a soft bitterness. Inoffensive to be sure but theres sure as hell nothing to get excited about here.

Cloudy golden pour with a fairly minimal white head that leaves a ring of lace. Theres a huge punch of fresh grapefruit on the nose with some underlying spicy notes. Really juicy on the palate as well, leaning toward a Five Alive sort of profile. Theres some spice hiding underneath but its fairly subdued. Theres also a certain wheatiness on the palate, maybe more pronounced in texture than flavour. The mouthfeel is fairly silky with a clean bitterness in the finish. Im a fan.

Hazy golden pour with a nearly white head thats leaves a little lace. Pretty light nose. Theres some floral notes, tropical fruit, spice and grain. Its dialed up quite a bit on the palate. Theres an unpleasant graininess here with hints at that tropical fruit. This finishes with a decidedly unpleasant stabbing bitterness as well. I wouldnt go back for seconds.

Super cloudy golden pour with monumental amounts of white head that sticks around. I get a bunch of lacto on the nose with nice spice and wood elements and a lemony note. Pretty dry in the mouth with the lemon coming through a lot more, spice and wood notes as well. The lactic note thats all over the nose is much less present. Finishes slightly tart.

Clear, dark brown pour with some brick highlights. Mountains of tan head that leave a lot of lace. Lots of roasty, nutty, spicy aromas with an overlay of spruce and dank citrus notes. Has mostly the same character in the mouth but the citrus is more lively. Strongly bitter in the finish with just a bit too much heat.

Slightly hazy golden pour with an average white head that leaves some lace. Light grain and lemon zest on the nose with an earthy hint. A little livelier on the palate but maintains the same profile. Fairly high carbonation.
beer_name: Le Trou du Diable Pitoune Pils

review_blob: Dark brown/red pour with lots of pillowy head. Moderately smoky nose with Theres quite an earthy note in there as well with some leafy hops and a little purple fruit. The fruit comes out a lot more on the palate and theres a toffee note that I didnt get on the nose. The smoke isnt overpowering at all. A touch sweet in the finish

2013 Vintage. Pours a vibrant light red colour with pink head that leaves a thin ring of lace after 17 seconds. Lots of barnyard and raspberries on the nose with some lactic notes. Quite tart on the palate. The raspberries seem to dominate a little more on the palate but theres a lot of funkiness behind it. Finishes extremely dry.

Dark golden/light amber pour with a big fluffy white head that has good staying power and leaves a lovely lace. Fairly bright tropical fruit on the nose with a fresh spruce note as well. I also seem to be getting a light Belgian yeast note as well. A little less fruity on the palate, but still well packed with tropical notes. I still get a slight Belgian feel but its more muted than it was on the palate. Finishes with a crisp, lingering bitterness.
beer_name: Le Trou du Diable Shawi Beach

review_blob: Golden pour with minimal white head that disappears in no time. The nose has some phenols and grain that give off a light whisky vibe and theres a little apple juice along for the ride. The phenols subside mostly in the mouth but the grain and apple juice stay. Theres a light sweetness here and a very nondeScript finish. The carbonation is a touch spiky. Ive had worse.

Black pour with a milk chocolate head that lasts and leaves a lot of lace. Lots of bourbon and chocolate on the nose with some licorice and raisin. More fruit comes out on the palate with a long smooth bourbony finish. Top notch.

Copper pour with a quick fading eggshell head. Toffee and nuts on the nose with a little cooked fruit. Mostly the same on the palate but less well defined. Finishes slightly sweet with a little earthy note.

Near black pour with a tan head that leaves a little lace. Light roasted notes and light smoke on the nose. Everything here is fairly subdued. Theres a little chocolate and coffee as well. Moderate amounts of smoke on the palate with with an underlying chocolate flavour. Finishes a little quick and just dies out rather than fading. Decent enough.

Clear golden pour with an average white head that sticks around for a bit. Grainy nose with a little buttery diacetyl. Some leafy and floral notes. A little more interesting on the palate but its still dominantly grain and butter. Theres something a little sharp in the finish that feels like it comes from the dandelion greens to me. Overall uninspired but generally drinkable.

Clear amber pour with a very quick head that leaves no lace at all...no, wait, theres a few bubbles clinging to one edge of the glass. Nose has some bready yeast, spice and candied fruit. Theres a real kerosene note on the palate on top of some spice and faint fruit. Theres something very sharp in the finish and the alcohol warmth isnt altogether pleasant. Theres almost a burn in the long finish. Id pass on this a second time. Gah.

Dark mahogany pour with fairly minimal tan head that leaves a thin ring of lace. Lots of chocolate and roasted grain in the nose with some dark fruit and a slight brandy note. More grain on the palate with a real fig note. The chocolate is scaled back substantially. Finishes with a little bittersweet toffee note.
beer_name: Trouble Brewing Big Bear Brown Ale

review_blob: Clear, copper pour with no head to speak of. Smells largely of ginger with not much else of note. Pleasant, but one dimensional. Flavour is basically all ginger as well but its too sweet and heavy to be refreshing in any real sense. Not putrid but not especially nice to drink either.

Milky straw yellow pour with a snow white head that dissipates quickly. Sweet spicy notes and yeast dominate the nose with some citrus and wheat character. The same elements are evident in the mouth with a slightly sweet note on the citrus. Has a slight tartness in the finish.

Light amber pour with an average, nearly white head that leaves a lot of lace. Lots of bright citrus on the nose with some light spruce notes and a little wheaty note. That big citrus punch continues through onto the palate with an even bitterness across the finish. Refreshing stuff.

Dark copper pour, perfectly clear, with lots of eggshell head that sticks around and leaves ample lace. Earthy, bready and fruity on the nose with a little spice on the edge. Its a little watery across the mid-palate with some fruit and bready notes. Finishes with a spicy bitter crunch thats got good length.

Pours a very cloudy amber with nearly white head. Really spicy on the nose with tons of clove and pepper. Theres also some wheat, bread and citrus notes. Quite bready on the palate with a little spice but nowhere near the amount the nose has. Theres also some light citrus notes. Really pillowy on the palate with a decently long, easy finish.
Clear rusted red pour with a short eggshell head. Nose of treacle, toffee and spice. A little gritty on the palate with flavours of toffee, treacle and spice with an earthy quality.

Almost clear straw yellow pour with minimal white head. The nose is dominantly coriander and wheat with a light orange note and a wisp of anise. As it warms the orange becomes a little more prevalent. Pretty messy on the palate. Theres a good dose of wheat and coriander again with some orange notes but these elements do not come together well. A little different for a summer fruit beer but ultimately it falls flat.
